results.title: Banjo's Australia
results.brief_description: This program explains A. B. Paterson’s contribution and significance to Australian literature from the 1890’s to the World War I. It traces Paterson’s personal history, his love of the bush, his admiration for camaraderie and spirit of the bush and the pathos and humour of bush life.

results.title: Bangkok Hilton
results.creator_credit: Kennedy Miller Productions, Terry Hayes, Doug Mitchell, George Miller and Ken Cameron
results.brief_description: 6 episode television mini series about young Australian outback heiress Katrina Stanton (Nicole Kidman) who, after her mother’s death learns that her father, supposedly dead, is in fact alive and living overseas. She sets out on a journey from outback Australia to London to trace him. Her London uncle, initially aloof, finally reveals that her father (Denholm Elliott) resides in Bangkok and has contact with him through the family solicitor there. While staying in London, Katrina is seduced by suave young drug dealer Arkie Ragan, who offers to accompany her to Australia via Bangkok and help her contact her father. He hides 8kg of heroin in her suitcase and she is arrested at Bangkok airport. Taken to the notorious “Bangkok Hilton”, she fights to survive conditions in the women’s prison while awaiting her trial, her only support being the family solicitor Richard Carlisle (Hugo Weaving) and, unknown to Katrina, her father who acts as the associate on the case. All legal channels are exhausted when Katrina is sentenced to death, and her only hope for survival is escape. This forces her father to confront some of his own demons.

results.title: Bangkok - the City of Angels/the Kingdom of Thailand
results.creator_credit: Australia. Special Broadcasting Service and Colin Baker
results.brief_description:
Episode of Series “A Travellers’ guide to the Orient”.
Bangkok: The City of Angels - Bangkok, capital of the Kingdom of Thailand is one of Asia’s most popular destinations. Enjoy the breathtaking Royal Palace, the ornate Royal Barges and Bangkok’s beautiful temples, the magic of the Viman Mek Teak Palace - “The Castle in the Clouds”, the world’s largest golden teak structure, the bustle of the Floating Markets, the ancient capital of Atyutthaya, the beautiful River Kwai (with its famous bridge), visit the Rose Garden and enjoy its exuberant and lavish stage presentation, complete with elephant show. Bangkok is famous for its food and shopping, contrast the tempo and excitement of modern day Bangkok, with the tranquil splendour of the Ancient City. “The Kingdom of Thailand” - Siam, as it was once known, with its delightful people, offers the traveller unlimited attractions - the fun and sun of Pattaya, the beauty of Chiang Mai, “Thailand’s Northern Shangri-la” with visits to the Hill Tribes and elephant camps, visit Chiang Rai and the famed Golden Triangle and join the wedding celebrations of a remote Hill tribe. Rated: G

results.title: Bangers. Feeling sexy
results.creator_credit: Binnaburra Film Company, Pacific Film and Television Commission., Andrew Upton, Cate Blanchett, Glenys Rowe and Davida Allen
results.brief_description: Bangers (1998, 9 min)- Julie-Anne (Cate Blanchett) comes home from a hard day at the office to discover that her mother (Lynette Curran) has locked the cat in the house all day and that she is expected to cook ‘bangers’ for dinner. Preparing the meal becomes a manifestation of all the repressed tension in Julie-Anne’s work and home life. “Feeling sexy” (1998, 50 min)- This film is renowned painter Davida Allen’s first feature film. Vicki (Susie Porter) is a passionate and vivacious artist whose love for lust and life is slowly being stifled by domestic doldrums. Unable to elicit appropriate responses from her doctor husband Greg (Tamblyn Lord), Vicki embarks on a carnal affair with art student Hugo. When Vicki confesses her indiscretion to Greg, punishment comes in the shape of a blue-heeler who nearly destroys the house and Vicki’s psyche. Novelty being the spice of life, Vicki will have to call on all the resources of her creativity and imagination to coax Greg along on the path to restoring their relationship.

results.title: Bangers
results.brief_description: A working woman arrives home to the apartment she shares with her mother to discover that the cat has been locked inside - again. It is a stark reminder of her mundane existence, and to make matters worse, sausages are on the menu again. As she cooks up the bangers she lets out all of her frustration. Cast includes Cate Blanchett and Lynette Curran as the mother and daughter.

results.title: Bangarra Dance Theatre: ochres (A)
results.creator_credit: Stephen Burstow, Bangarra Dance Theatre and ABC-TV (Australia)
results.brief_description: Recorded during the 1996 Festival of Perth, this production is an exemplary work from the dancers and musicians of the Bangarra Dance Theatre Company, Australia, acclaimed for its fusion of contemporary dance and indigenous traditional styles as well as original musical scores. The performance is centred around the substance Ochres, a material with both physical and spiritual purposes in traditional and urban Aboriginal culture, and from which Stephen Page drew inspiration for his original creation of the choreography for the production in 1994. The dance performance is structured around the characteristics, qualities and variety of symbolic significances of the substance. Divided into 5 parts, it begins with the spirit of Ochres, ‘the light’, then the performance shifts to a study of Ochres’ four essential colours; yellow, black, red and white. The performance features Bangarra Dance Theatre Company artists Gary Lang, Marilyn Miller, Djakapurra Munyarryun, Russell Page, Albert David, Kathryn Dunn, Frances Rings and Gina Rings in a seamless video capture of a powerful dance work.

results.title: Bang the drum slowly. - Edited Version.
results.creator_credit: Maurice Rosenfield, Lois Rosenfield and John Hancock
results.brief_description: Edited version of the feature film based on Mark Harris’s classic story of friendship, compassion and death set against a background of major-league baseball. Robert de Niro stars as the baseball hero who discovers that he is dying of leukemia.

results.title: Banduk (Captioned)
results.creator_credit: Penelope Spence, National Nine Network and Di Drew
results.brief_description: Banduk, a young Aboriginal girl, and her friends discover that the “friendly” proprietors of an ice-cream van are smuggling native animals, including the sacred red-collared parakeet, out of Australia. This delightful story was filmed on location in Arnhem Land.
results.creator_credit_for_label: Penelope Spence, National Nine Network and Di Drew

results.title: Bandits [DVD]
results.creator_credit: Metro-Goldwyn-Mayer, Michael Birnbaum, Michele Berk, Barry Levinson and Paula Weinstein
results.brief_description: Escaping from prison in a cement truck, rugged ladies-man Joe (Bruce Willis) and neurotic hypochondriac Terry (Billy Bob Thornton), find themselves criminal celebrities when they come upon a new way of robbing banks - sleeping over at the house of their victims the night before the heist. With paradise firmly in mind - a nightclub in Acapulco - the affable robbers target bank managers, sleep over, then catch a ride into work before robbing it. Their modus operandi garners them the moniker of the “Sleepover bandits.” Trouble ensues when the men separate and make their own way to the rendezvous. Terry runs out of petrol and ends up being “kidnapped” by manic-depressive housewife Kate (Cate Blanchett), who accidentally hits him with her car. Eager to make it up to him and nonplussed at being removed from her loveless marriage, Kate calls herself a bandit too - but not before endearing herself to both men who fall in love with her. Told in flashback and presented as part of a tell all scoop on “Criminals at large”, “Bandits” also features Troy Garity as Joe’s cousin; getaway driver, wannabe stuntman and pursuer of a mystery female hitchhiker. A curious blend of comedy, action and road movie, “Bandits” was originally intended as an adaptation of the Elmore Leonard book of the same name. Instead, the script was completely rewritten by Harvey Peyton (Twin Peaks).
